author: un7c0rn
content: I've been trying to wrap my head around the data availability problem and how it relates to L2 scaling solutions and I feel like there's a gap in my understanding / reading of the material that's out there. I think I get the idea that a node can construct a block which withholds transactions, yet is still a valid block, but I don't quite see how that creates an advantage.

author: un7c0rn
content: I'm also confused about how rollups solve this, e.g. by requiring transactions / calldata to be written to L1 –– couldn't the L2 operator still withhold from writing those transactions to the main chain, in the same way that it would withhold them from blocks on L2?
